Human aging is a complex, multi-factorial process that involves the gradual deterioration of the human body over time. It is a universal experience that affects every living organism, yet its underlying mechanisms are still not fully understood. While aging is often viewed as a single, unidirectional process, research suggests that it is comprised of multiple, interconnected pathways that influence an individual's physical and cognitive abilities. The human body is made up of approximately 37 trillion cells, each with its own unique lifespan, and the accumulation of cellular damage over time contributes to the aging process. Telomere shortening, epigenetic changes, and the activation of senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) are just a few of the key cellular mechanisms that have been implicated in aging. Furthermore, the interplay between genetic and environmental factors, such as lifestyle choices and exposure to stress, also plays a significant role in determining an individual's rate of aging. Human aging refers to the biological and physiological changes that occur in individuals as they get older. This process is influenced by a combination of genetic, environmental, and lifestyle factors. As people age, their cells and organs undergo various changes, such as the loss of cellular integrity, reduced metabolic function, and increased oxidative stress. These changes can lead to the development of age-related diseases, including cardiovascular disease, cancer, and neurodegenerative disorders.

Aging can be divided into two main categories: intrinsic and extrinsic aging. Intrinsic aging is a natural process that occurs due to the accumulation of genetic damage and cellular wear and tear over time. Extrinsic aging, on the other hand, is influenced by external factors such as lifestyle choices, environmental exposures, and infections. While some age-related changes are inevitable, research has shown that certain lifestyle modifications, such as regular exercise, a balanced diet, and stress management, can help mitigate the effects of aging and promote healthy aging. At the cellular level, aging is characterized by the accumulation of damage to DNA, proteins, and other cellular components, which can lead to the degradation of cellular function and the disruption of normal cellular processes. This damage can be caused by a variety of factors, including environmental stressors such as UV radiation, oxidative stress, and inflammation, as well as genetic mutations that can disrupt normal cellular function.
